a misreading of a statement by Davies

81 It is difficult to calculate human capabilities with respect to driving irrigation machinery without constructing full-scale models. Even leaving aside the questions of the average body weight and physical condition of Egyptian peasants or maltreated slaves in Roman mines, there are no calculations of the present human capacity for work in situations exactly parallel to those of the compartmented wheel or water-screw. Various treadmill and stair-climbing exercises have shown an adult male capable of ca 0.20-0.22 hp

note: I prefer to calculate possible output at 0.1 hp, as does Landels ( 1978
title: 261. Treading a compartmented wheel, however, quite probably was harder, and it certainly was expected to continue for longer periods of time than these 418 Notes to pp 350-6 tests. The poor physical condition of slaves in particular, and their understandable disinclination to work at top efficiency should also be taken into account

note: Keuls The Water Carriers in Hades (Amsterdam 1974) does not provide any support. 84 Plutarch Marcellus 14-17 85 See chapter 3, categorized list 4.
title: makes the enticing suggestion that the legend of the daughters of Dana us, condemned in Hades to carry water in leaky buckets for eternity, is a veiled description of an Egyptian bucket-chain. Danaus and his daughters came from Egypt, according to the myth, and they supposedly taught the people of the Argo lid how to dig wells. There is a historical basis for the myth of Egyptian immigration in the Bronze Age
but in the absence of any concrete evidence for the existence of the bucket-chain in the Bronze Age, Ewbank's suggestion must be rejected

The gear-driven irrigation devices of Morocco, discussed by Colin ( 1932) 22-60 and ( 1933) 156-7, undoubtedly stem from the same traditions as the neighbouring Spanish devices. 419 Notes to
title: 98 notes quite rightly that there is a gap between the Roman and the Arabic irrigation systems in Spain. The Arabs probably did not find many mechanical irrigation devices in use upon their arrival there, but reintroduced traditions that had survived in the eastern Mediterranean. For the Arabic role in the transmission of ancient science to the medieval West, see A.C. Crombie Medieval and Early Modern Science
